definition[0]: to arrange or organize something that is mixed up or untidy, so that it is ready to be used
example[0]: We need to sort out our camping gear before we go away.
definition[1]: to separate one type of thing from another
example[1]: I’ve sorted out the papers that can be thrown away.
example[2]: First, sort the white things out from the other clothes.
definition[2]: to successfully deal with a problem or difficult situation
example[3]: She went to a psychiatrist to try to sort out her problems.
example[4]: I’ll be glad to get this misunderstanding sorted out.
example[5]: I’m staying with a friend until I manage to sort myself out.
note[0]: sort yourself out/get yourself sorted out
definition[3]: to succeed in making arrangements for something
example[6]: Have you sorted out where you’re going to live yet?
example[7]: She is trying to sort out childcare.
definition[4]: if something sorts itself out, it stops being a problem without you having to do anything
example[8]: Our financial problems should sort themselves out in a week or two.
definition[5]: to stop someone from causing problems or annoying you, especially by attacking or punishing them
example[9]: If he bothers you again, I’ll sort him out.
definition[6]: an occasion when you tidy a room, desk etc and get rid of the things you do not need
example[10]: These cupboards need a good sort-out.
